speaker: Mitt Romney
vclaim: "McCain" was opposed to ethanol. And now he's okay with it."
date: stated on April 26, 2007 in Stratham, N.H.:
title: McCann came to favor ethanol.
text: With regard to ethanol, Makin maintained long-term opposition to alternative fuel subsidies and this has not changed. But the way he talks about ethanol has changed a lot. In 1999, I told an audience in Iowa, where corn-based ethanol is famous: "I'm here to tell you what you don't want to hear and what you want to hear. One of these things is ethanol. Ethanol isn't worth it. This does not help consumers. These ethanol subsidies should be phased out. And everyone here on this podium, if it weren't for the fact that Iowa is the first state to gather, share my view that we don't need Ethanol subsidies." In 2007, McCain began to speak better about ethanol and admitted that he had changed his position. He told Tim Rossiert in "Meet the press": "That makes a lot of sense. We depend too much on foreign oil. We have a situation where greenhouse gases are now -- emissions are becoming a vital issue. I'm for sugar cane, biofuels, grass replacement, corn-based ethanol because we need foreign oil independence. I have adapted to the realities of the world in which we live today, and if I do not adapt to those realities, then I will be stuck in the past."
